text: Is the documentation for dnd rows and columns accurate? <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/tags/dnd-areas#dnd-row> For instance, `max_width` doesn’t seem to do anything for me.

Hi all! Has anybody has a good idea how to use svg’s in webpages. I dont’ want to use <img src=“path/to/svg/file.svg” because i’d like to change color, stroke, etc with css.

So i want to use the full svg code in the html code.. i was thinking of creating a hubdb table, make a macro of it with its name as a variable so its easy to use. Thinking out loud here. please let me know what you guys would do/have done to make this work!
a macro, or a partial is probably easier to use if you have a handful - I suppose it depends what you're trying to do.
want to make it so i can easily use svg’s inline basically
i’ve tried to create a svgsheet, put them all in there, but that won’t work if more svg’s will be added to this, because the pageload would suffer tremendously

You could use CSS to change the style of an SVG. It works but it’s a little bit a different syntax as I figured. I sometimes use it to change the SVG color in the header depend of the scrolling.
<https://css-tricks.com/using-svg/>

Hi all, I am currently working on the Product pages for a client

Here's how I used Hubdb to create the dynamic pages
1. Created a Hubdb for Products, this have columns such as the Product name, product category, product sub category, and other details.
2. Created normal pages for product subcategory and attached the hubdb. This way I achieved the
product-category/product-subcategory/product-name URL

The issue:
This approach created each rows a dynamic pages on each normal pages that uses the same HubDB. A major redundacy and issues on SEO part.

Can someone please help me on this.

option 1:
If you don’t need dynamic pages, you should turn them off. You can still store data in the HUBDB and pull it from there.

option 2:
Get rid of your internal product pages and use the dynamic pages only.

Also, why are you using product-category/product-subcategory? Seems like an awful lot of work for no gain for anyone. This doesn’t affect SEO like it once did, and why have an overly long URL? Create breadcrumbs on your pages if you want to show this type of hierarchy — I see zero value of creating a complex url structure.

If I were doing this, I’d use dynamic pages, I’d set this up as products/product-slug, and have breadcrumbs. I realize I don’t have all of the project requirements in here, that is why I offer option 1 and 2

Does anyone know if HubSpot is deprecating the Blog_Social_Share default module?

I'm very suddenly getting this error related to including this default module in a Blog_Post template.
